description: From the late Middle English medioker, from the French médiocre, from the Middle French médiocre, from the Classical Latin mediocris (“in a middle state”, “of middle size”, “middling”, “moderate”, “ordinary”), from medius (“middle”) + ocris (“rugged mountain”); compare mediocrely and mediocrity.

adjectives.description: mediocre (comparative more mediocre, superlative most mediocre)

entries.meaning: Having no peculiar or outstanding features; not extraordinary, special, exceptional, or great; of medium quality, almost always with a negative connotation.
examples: I'm pretty good at tennis but only mediocre at racquetball.

entries.meaning: A person of minor significance, accomplishment or acclaim; a common and undistinguished person.
examples: After this lecture, how do the mediocres feel? They probably feel indifferent or mad. Perhaps they were not even paying attention. The question is, are they more likely to be in the hallway tomorrow? Probably not.

entries.meaning: (historical) A member of a socioeconomic class between the upper ranks of society and the agricultural workers.
